steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at how much of the top bar is shaded, then shade the same amount on the bottom bar.

Let's think about this together. The top bar shows 2 out of 4 parts shaded - that's half the bar. Now look at the bottom bar with 6 parts. How many parts would be half of 6? Shade that many parts to match the same amount.

Let me walk you through this. The top bar has 2 out of 4 parts shaded. Notice that 2 out of 4 is exactly half of the bar. Now we need to shade half of the bottom bar too. The bottom bar has 6 equal parts, so half of 6 is 3. We need to shade 3 parts to show the same amount. That makes 3/6, which equals 2/4 - they both represent one half. That's how equivalent fractions work - different numbers of parts, but the same total amount.
